greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of primes p<=n such that 2n-p and 2n+p-2 are both prime
comment: This is stronger than the Goldbach conjecture; it has been verified for n up to 5*10^7.
Zhi-Wei Sun also conjectured that if n is not among 1,2,3,5,8,87,108 then there is a prime p in (n,2n)
such that 2n-p and 2n+p-2 are both prime. For conjectures in Section 2 of arXiv:1211.1588, he had similar conjectures with p<=n replaced by p in (n,2n)
For example, if n is not among 1,2,4,6,10,15 then there is a prime p in (n,2n) such that
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000.
Zhi-Wei Sun, Conjectures involving primes and quadratic forms, arXiv:1211.1588v2.
example: a(8)=2 since 3 and 5 are the only primes p<=8 with 16-p and 14+p both prime.
mathematica: np[n_]:=Count[Prime[Range[PrimePi[n]]],_?(AllTrue[{2n-#,2n+#-2},PrimeQ]&)]; Array[np,100] (* The program uses the AllTrue function from Mathematica version 10 *) (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Sep 23 2017 *)
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 10 2012
